hero.subtitle: Transforming Communication in the Age of Artificial Intelligence
hero.description: Explore the journey of technological evolution and discover how AI is revolutionizing communication in the healthcare sector with KnowYOU.
hero.ctaHealthTooltip: Navigate to the interactive KnowYOU section to chat with the health assistant
hero.ctaHistoryTooltip: Open interactive timeline showing the evolution of Artificial Intelligence since 1950
hero.quote: The exact moment we stopped just operating machines and started, in fact, thinking with them.

software.title: The First Revolution
software.subtitle: 1940s-1980
software.quote: The exact moment we stopped just operating machines and started, in fact, thinking with them.
software.content1: Software represented the first major communication between humans and machines. Through programming languages, we were able to instruct computers to perform complex tasks. It was rigid, technical communication, accessible only to specialists.
software.content2: This era marked the beginning of digital transformation, establishing the foundation for all technological revolutions that would follow.

internet.title: The Age of Connectivity
internet.subtitle: 1990s-2000
internet.quote: The internet didn't just shorten geographical distances; it intertwined humanity's destiny into a single pulsating network.
internet.content1: The Internet democratized access to information and completely transformed how we communicate. Suddenly, the entire world was connected, sharing knowledge on a global scale.
internet.content2: This revolution not only connected computers, but connected people, cultures, and ideas in ways never before imagined.

techNoPropose.title: The Technology Hype
techNoPropose.quote: Without a clear purpose, innovation ceases to be a tool of progress and becomes merely a sophisticated distraction.
techNoPropose.content1: Not every technological innovation finds its purpose. The Metaverse and NFTs promised to revolutionize the digital world, but lacked practical application and real value to users.
techNoPropose.content2: This phase taught us valuable lessons about the difference between technological innovation and innovation with real purpose for society.

kubrick.title: Kubrick's Prophecy
kubrick.subtitle: 1969 - 2001: A Space Odyssey
kubrick.quote: Now that the fiction of 2001 has become reality, the mystery is no longer the machine's capability, but the human intention behind it.
kubrick.content1: In 1969, Stanley Kubrick introduced us to HAL 9000, an AI that not only processed commands, but conversed, understood context, and had personality. It was an impressive premonition of the future we're living today.
kubrick.content2: What seemed like science fiction 50 years ago became reality with the advent of large language models and conversational AI assistants.

watson.title: Watson: The Age of Cognition
watson.subtitle: 2004 - IBM Watson
watson.quote: By teaching a machine to read nuances, we discovered that true intelligence isn't in giving answers, but in understanding the questions.
watson.content1: IBM Watson marked the beginning of the cognitive era, demonstrating that machines could not only process data, but understand natural language, reason, and learn.
watson.content2: Its victory on Jeopardy! in 2011 was a historic milestone, proving that AI could compete with humans in tasks requiring broad knowledge and contextual understanding.

newEra.title: The New AI Era
newEra.subtitle: 2022 - Present
newEra.quote: By democratizing intelligence, we're not just updating the world's software, but rewriting each human being's potential.
newEra.content1: With ChatGPT and similar models, we entered a new era where communication with machines is natural, fluid, and accessible to everyone. The technical barrier has been eliminated.
newEra.content2: Now, anyone can converse with an AI as they would with a human expert, opening infinite possibilities in education, health, business, and much more.

knowyou.title: KnowYOU: Reskilling in the AI Era
knowyou.subtitle: Conversational Technology in Healthcare
knowyou.content1: The Long Tail problem reveals a critical challenge: most people don't know how to communicate effectively with AI. This is where KnowYOU comes in.
knowyou.content2: Our conversational technology was specially developed for the healthcare sector, making AI communication natural and productive for all professionals, regardless of their technical knowledge.

goodPrompt.title: The Art of Good Prompting
goodPrompt.subtitle: Effective Communication with AI
goodPrompt.quote: The quality of the answer depends on the quality of the question.
goodPrompt.content1: Knowing how to ask the right questions is fundamental in the AI era. A good prompt is clear, specific, contextualized, and directed to the desired objective.
goodPrompt.content2: KnowYOU not only answers your questions but teaches you to communicate better with AI, developing an essential skill for the future of healthcare work.
goodPrompt.beSpecificDesc: Instead of 'talk about diabetes,' ask 'what are the main indicators for diagnosing type 2 diabetes in adults?'
goodPrompt.giveContextDesc: Explain your situation, your role, and what you need to achieve with the answer.
goodPrompt.iterateRefineDesc: Don't be afraid to ask follow-up questions to get exactly the information you need.

digitalExclusion.title: 5.74 billion
digitalExclusion.subtitle: people still cannot access the internet
digitalExclusion.content1: While we celebrate advances in artificial intelligence and its capacity to transform industries, communication, and knowledge, a disturbing reality remains: 5.74 billion people worldwide still don't have internet access. This digital exclusion represents not just a technological barrier, but an abyss of opportunities that widens exponentially in the generative AI era.
digitalExclusion.content2: The democratization of artificial intelligence fundamentally depends on connectivity access. Without internet, billions of people are excluded not only from AI tools but also from the literacy needed to understand, question, and use these technologies critically and productively.
digitalExclusion.content3: Beyond infrastructure barriers, we face linguistic and cognitive challenges: most AI models are trained predominantly in English, and even when available in other languages, require a level of digital literacy that much of the global population still lacks. The true AI revolution will only be complete when we manage to include these 5.74 billion voices in the conversation.

timeline.title: The Definitive Timeline: From Talos to the AI Fever

talos.title: Talos, the Bronze Giant
talos.description:
What it is: A bronze automaton, made by Hephaestus, designed to protect the island of Crete.

Impact on AI: Talos is the first philosophical concept of an autonomous machine. Although mythical, it establishes the human idea of creating an artificial being with a specific purpose (security/surveillance) that operates without constant human intervention. This plants the seed for Robotics and Autonomous Agent Systems, precursors of bots and modern operational AI.

telegraphy-cards.title: Telegraphy and Punched Cards
telegraphy-cards.description:
Telegraphy: The earliest form of telegraphy (Claude Chappe's optical telegraph) emerged in the late 18th century (c. 1790). The electric telegraph, revolutionary for communication and data encoding, was developed by Samuel Morse and Alfred Vail from 1837.

Punched Cards: First used in the Jacquard Loom (1801) to automate weaving patterns. Herman Hollerith popularized their use for data processing and storage in the 1890 US census.

Impact on AI: Established the foundations of information encoding and automated data processing, direct precursors of modern computing.

turing-machine.title: Turing Machine
turing-machine.description: Alan Turing establishes the theoretical foundation of computing, describing the abstract model of a universal computer capable of solving any computable problem.

enigma.title: Breaking the Enigma Code
enigma.description: Alan Turing uses precursor machines to digital computers (Bombes) to decipher German encryption, linking logical machines to information security.

turing-test.title: Turing Test
turing-test.description: Alan Turing proposes the 'Imitation Game', which becomes the philosophical goal of Artificial Intelligence: creating machines that can converse like humans.

arpanet.title: ARPANET - First Connection
arpanet.description: The embryo of the Internet, using packet switching to create a decentralized and fault-resistant network. First message sent between computers.

tcpip.title: TCP/IP Concept
tcpip.description: Vinton Cerf and Robert Kahn establish the TCP/IP protocol, the fundamental language that enables global communication between heterogeneous networks.

www.title: World Wide Web (WWW)
www.description: Tim Berners-Lee proposes the hypertext system (links), making the Internet accessible and navigable to the general public through web browsers.

social.title: Facebook and Orkut - Web 2.0
social.description: Beginning of Web 2.0, focused on social interaction and user-generated content. Social networks transform how we communicate online.

watson.title: IBM Watson wins Jeopardy!
watson.description: IBM's Watson supercomputer defeats human champions on Jeopardy!, demonstrating AI's ability to process Natural Language and complex knowledge in real-time.

openai.title: OpenAI Foundation
openai.description: Organization created with the goal of ensuring that Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) benefits all of humanity, prioritizing safety and ethics.

gpt3.title: GPT-3 Launch
gpt3.description: The language model generates texts indistinguishable from human-written texts. Revolutionizes natural language processing and drives research in Large Language Models.

chatgpt.title: ChatGPT Launch
chatgpt.description: The GPT-3.5 chat interface becomes a viral phenomenon. Marks the beginning of the 'AI Fever', making generative AI a mass consumer tool.

current.title: Web 3.0, Veo and LLMs
current.description: Consolidation of Generative AI (LLMs like Gemini and GPT-4), video creation tools like Veo, and the expansion of the Internet of Things. AI becomes an essential part of Internet infrastructure.

dream.title: The Dream (Before 1950)
dream.subtitle: Where everything was science fiction and human desire.
items: Antiquity: Greek myths already spoke of automatons and statues that came to life (like Talos, the bronze giant).
1843 - The 'Grandmother' of Programming: Ada Lovelace writes the first algorithm for a machine.
1920 - The word 'Robot' is born: A Czech play (R.U.R.) uses the term for the first time.

birth.title: The Birth (1950s)
birth.subtitle: Where AI gains a name and takes its first steps.
items: 1950 - The Turing Test: Alan Turing poses the question: 'Can machines think?'
1956 - The Baptism: Dartmouth Conference officially coins the term 'Artificial Intelligence'.
1957 - Perceptron: Frank Rosenblatt creates a machine that tries to mimic a neuron.

childhood.title: Childhood and Adolescence (1960s to 1980s)
childhood.subtitle: Ups and downs, rebellion, and Hollywood movies.
items: 1966 - ELIZA, the 'Psychologist': The first chatbot in history!
1970s - The AI Winter: Promises were too big and technology didn't deliver.
1980s - The Return: AI comes back with 'Expert Systems'.
The Terminator (1984): Cinema creates the image of AI as a villain.

adulthood.title: The Adult Phase (1990s and 2000s)
adulthood.subtitle: AI starts beating humans and entering our homes.
items: 1997 - Checkmate: Computer Deep Blue (IBM) defeats Garry Kasparov at chess.
2002 - Roomba: AI enters your living room... to vacuum.
2011 - 'Hey, Siri': We start talking to our phones.

revolution.title: The Generative Revolution (2010s to Today)
revolution.subtitle: AI stops just analyzing and starts CREATING.
items: 2012 - The 'Big Bang' of Deep Learning: Neural networks learn to identify cats on YouTube by themselves.
2016 - AlphaGo: AI defeats the world Go champion with 'creative' moves.
2017 - The Transformer: Google publishes a paper that changes everything.
2022/2023 - The ChatGPT and Gemini Era: AI 'breaks out of the cage'.

tts.title: TTS, Phonetics and Artificial Intelligence
tts.intro: stands for **Text-to-Speech**. In the context of Artificial Intelligence and phonetics, it refers to technology that converts written text into synthetic spoken audio, simulating the human voice.
tts.description: It's not just about "reading" words, but understanding how those words should sound based on linguistic rules and deep learning models.

pipeline.title: 1. The Process Flow (Pipeline)
pipeline.intro: For an AI to transform text into speech, it goes through critical stages where phonetics is essential:
pipeline.step1: **Text Normalization:** The AI converts numbers, abbreviations, and symbols into full words.
pipeline.step2: **Grapheme-to-Phoneme Conversion (G2P):** This is where the phonetics magic happens. The system translates writing (graphemes) into sound representation (phonemes).
pipeline.step2Example: *Example:* The word "house" is internally converted to something like `/h/ /a ä/ /s/`.
pipeline.step3: **Prosodic Analysis:** The AI determines rhythm, intonation (question vs. statement), and emphasis (stress).
pipeline.step4: **Audio Synthesis:** The computer generates the final sound waves based on these instructions.

phoneticsRole.title: 2. The Role of Phonetics in AI
phoneticsRole.intro: Phonetics in modern TTS is not just a pronunciation dictionary; it's a dynamic interpretation system.
phoneticsRole.disambiguation: **Homograph Disambiguation:** The AI needs to analyze context to know which phoneme to use for words spelled the same but pronounced differently.
phoneticsRole.disambiguationExample: *Example:* "I will **read** the book" (present) vs. "I have **read** the book" (past).
phoneticsRole.coarticulation: **Coarticulation:** In human speech, a letter's sound is influenced by neighboring letters. Good TTS uses AI to smooth these transitions, preventing speech from sounding "robotic" or choppy.
phoneticsRole.prosody: **Prosody and Emotion:** Modern neural models (like those from OpenAI or ElevenLabs) analyze text semantics to apply correct emotion (sadness, excitement, doubt) in phrase phonetics.

comparison.title: 3. Evolution: Parametric vs. Neural TTS
comparison.methodNeural: Generates sound waves from scratch using neural networks.
comparison.flexibilityNeural: Can clone voices or change styles easily.

technologies.title: 4. Main Technologies
technologies.intro: Today, the most advanced TTS models use architectures such as:
technologies.tacotron: **Tacotron 2:** Maps text directly to spectrograms (visual representations of sound).
technologies.wavenet: **WaveNet / WaveGlow:** Generate raw audio waves point by point, resulting in very high fidelity.
technologies.valle: **VALL-E / XTTS:** Models capable of cloning voice and room acoustics with just a few seconds of reference audio.

rag.title: RAG: Retrieval-Augmented Generation
rag.intro: **RAG** stands for **Retrieval-Augmented Generation**. It's an AI architecture that combines information retrieval with text generation, allowing language models to respond based on specific documents.

whatIs.title: 1. What is RAG?
whatIs.intro: RAG is a hybrid paradigm that unites two worlds:
whatIs.retrieval: **Retrieval:** A semantic search system finds the most relevant documents for the user's question.
whatIs.generation: **Augmented Generation:** The LLM receives these documents as additional context to ground its response.
whatIs.result: *Result:* Accurate, up-to-date answers grounded in verifiable sources.

comparison.title: 2. Why is RAG Superior to Pure LLM?
comparison.customizationRag: Just add documents to the index

pipeline.title: 3. The Implemented RAG Pipeline
pipeline.step1: **Ingestion (ETL):** Documents are processed, validated, and fragmented into optimized chunks.
pipeline.step2: **Vector Indexing:** Each chunk is converted to an embedding and stored with pgvector.
pipeline.step3: **Hybrid Search:** Combines semantic similarity + metadata filters (tags, chat_type).
pipeline.step4: **Grounded Generation:** The LLM receives relevant chunks as mandatory context.

technical.title: 4. Technical Components
technical.threshold: **Threshold:** Minimum similarity of 0.15 for context inclusion

embeddings.title: Embeddings and Vector Similarity
embeddings.intro: are numerical representations of text that capture semantic meaning. They allow computers to 'understand' and compare texts mathematically.

whatIs.title: 1. What are Embeddings?
whatIs.content: Embeddings are vectors of numbers that represent words, phrases, or documents in a mathematical space. Texts with similar meanings are close in this space, enabling semantic searches.

models.title: 2. Embedding Models
models.intro: Different models generate embeddings with distinct characteristics:

similarity.title: 3. Similarity Calculation
similarity.intro: We measure how 'close' two embeddings are using:
similarity.cosine: **Cosine Similarity:** Measures the angle between vectors (0 = different, 1 = identical). Used in the system.
similarity.euclidean: **Euclidean Distance:** Direct geometric distance between points.
similarity.dot: **Dot Product:** Considers vector magnitude, useful for recommendations.

quality.title: 4. Quality Criteria
quality.criterion1: **Well-structured chunks:** Coherent and complete texts (ideally 200-800 words).
quality.criterion2: **Preserved context:** Avoid cuts in the middle of sentences or concepts.
quality.criterion3: **Semantic density:** Chunks with rich and relevant content, not just connectors.

glossary.title: 5. Glossary
glossary.vector: **Vector** - Ordered list of numbers representing a concept
glossary.dimension: **Dimension** - Number of values in the vector (e.g., 1536)
glossary.distance: **Distance** - Measure of difference between two vectors
glossary.similarity: **Similarity** - Measure of proximity between two vectors (inverse of distance)

chunks.title: Chunks and Fragmentation
chunks.intro: are document fragments optimized for semantic search. The fragmentation strategy directly impacts RAG response quality.

whatIs.title: 1. What are Chunks?
whatIs.content: Chunks are text units into which documents are divided for RAG processing. Each chunk receives its own embedding and is indexed independently, enabling granular search for relevant excerpts.

strategy.title: 2. Fragmentation Strategies
strategy.intro: There are different ways to divide documents:
strategy.fixedSize: **Fixed Size:** Divides by number of words or tokens (used in this system: ~750 words).
strategy.semantic: **Semantic:** Divides by paragraphs, sections, or complete topics.
strategy.overlap: **Overlap:** Chunks share words at borders to preserve context (180 words overlap).

impact.title: 4. Impact on RAG
impact.precision: **Precision:** Small chunks lose context; large ones mix multiple topics.
impact.context: **Context:** Overlap preserves continuity between adjacent chunks.
impact.performance: **Performance:** More chunks = more searches, but greater granularity.

glossary.title: 5. Glossary
glossary.chunk: **Chunk** - Document fragment with size optimized for search
glossary.window: **Window** - Chunk size in words or tokens
glossary.token: **Token** - Basic text unit (~0.75 words in Portuguese)

vectorStore.title: Vector Store and pgvector
vectorStore.intro: is the component responsible for storing and searching vector representations (embeddings) of text. It enables semantic similarity searches instead of exact word matching.

whatIs.title: 1. What is a Vector Store?
whatIs.content: A Vector Store is a specialized database for storing high-dimensional vectors and performing similarity searches. Each document chunk is converted into a numerical vector (embedding) that captures its semantic meaning.

pgvector.title: 2. Why pgvector?
pgvector.intro: pgvector is a PostgreSQL extension that adds native vector support:
pgvector.feature1: **Native Integration:** Works directly in existing PostgreSQL, no separate database needed.
pgvector.feature2: **Performance:** Supports HNSW and IVFFlat indexes for fast searches across millions of vectors.
pgvector.feature3: **Simplicity:** Combines structured data (metadata, tags) with vector search in the same query.

similarity.title: 3. Similarity Metrics
similarity.intro: The system supports different ways to measure how "close" two vectors are:

howItWorks.title: 4. How Search Works
howItWorks.step1: **Query ‚Üí Embedding:** User's question is converted into the same vector space as documents.
howItWorks.step2: **ANN Search:** Approximate Nearest Neighbor finds closest vectors without scanning all.
howItWorks.step3: **Threshold:** Only vectors with similarity above 0.15 are considered relevant.
howItWorks.step4: **Reranking:** Results are sorted and top-K are sent to the LLM.

glossary.title: 5. Technical Glossary
glossary.vector: **Vector** - Array of numbers representing a concept in semantic space
glossary.embedding: **Embedding** - Vector generated by AI model (e.g., text-embedding-3-small)
glossary.dimension: **Dimension** - Number of values in the vector (1536 in this system)
glossary.index: **HNSW Index** - Data structure for fast vector search
